abstract.text: The bacterial bipartite transferrin receptor is an iron acquisition system that is required for 12 survival by several key human and animal pathogens. It consists of the TonB-dependent 13 transporter Transferrin binding protein A (TbpA) and the surface lipoprotein Transferrin binding 14 protein B (TbpB). Curiously, the Tbps are only found in host specific pathogens, and are 15 themselves host specific, meaning that they will bind to the transferrin of their host species, but 16 not to those of other animal species. While this phenomenon has long been established, neither 17 the steps in the evolutionary process that led to this exquisite adaptation for the host, nor the 18 steps that could alter it, are known. We sought to gain insight into these processes by studying 19

Tbp specificity in Histophilus somni, a major pathogen of cattle. A past study showed that whole 20 cells of H. somni specifically bind bovine transferrin, but not transferrin from sheep and goats, 21 two bovids whose transferrins share 93% amino acid sequence identity with bovine transferrin. 22

To our surprise, we found that H. somni can use sheep and goat transferrins as iron sources for 23 growth, and that HsTbpB, but not HsTbpA, has detectable affinity for sheep and goat 24 transferrins. Furthermore, a third transferrin binding protein, HsTbpA2, also showed affinity for 25 sheep and goat transferrins. Our results show that H. somni TbpB and TbpA2 act to broaden the 26 host transferrin recognition range of H. somni. 27

body_text.text: Virulence factor specificity arises over the course of evolutionary arms races between pathogens 49 and their hosts (1-4). In this conflict, mutations that help the host evade the pathogen confer a 50 fitness advantage, and in turn, compensatory mutations that allow the pathogen to continue 51 exploiting the host confer an advantage to the pathogen. After multiple rounds of coevolution, 52 the pathogen becomes uniquely adapted to the host and may lose affinity for proteins found in 53 other host species, resulting in specificity (5). Host-species-specific interactions have been 54 identified in a virulence factor known as the bacterial bipartite transferrin receptor (6). This 55 . In order to see if we could recapitulate the results of the previously published study, we 125 performed a binding experiment with whole fixed cells of H. somni strain H191. We performed a 126 competitive assay known as a displacement ELISA, and looked at binding of whole fixed cells of 127 H. somni to bovine, ovine, caprine, and porcine transferrins. Cattle, sheep, and goats are known 128 hosts of H. somni while swine are not, and so porcine transferrin was used as a negative control 129 ( Figure 1A ). H. somni bound bovine transferrin, as expected, but also displayed some affinity for 130 ovine transferrin. There was no statistically significant binding to the caprine or porcine 131 transferrins ( Figure 1B) . 132

Next, we asked whether H. somni selectively uses bovine transferrin for growth, or whether its 133 binding of ovine transferrin leads to iron uptake from both of these iron sources. We measured 134 growth in the presence of bovine, ovine, caprine, and human transferrins at various 135 concentrations, as well as in buffer alone ( Figure 1C We wondered if the relatively low levels of growth on ovine and caprine transferrin at 25 µM 145 was due to a lower number of transferrin receptors being expressed at the cell surface under more 146 stringent conditions. This low expression may be due to the sudden shift between an iron-replete 147 and iron-starving environment. To address this, we performed another experiment where we 148 "pre-starved" the cells by growing them under iron-limiting conditions that were not as stringent 149 as those used in the previous experiment (see Methods) . In this case, following the pre-starvation 150 step, cells showed growth in the presence of bovine, ovine, and caprine transferrins at 25 µM 151 when compared to growth on human transferrin or buffer alone ( Figure 1D ). 152

We concluded that H. somni H191 does not exhibit strict specificity for bovine transferrin. 153 However, it does display a preference for bovine transferrin while also having affinity for 154 transferrins of other bovids. To determine which transferrin binding protein(s) was responsible 155 for this binding profile, we went on to investigate each Tbp separately in a heterologous system. To address the binding contribution of each of the transferrin binding proteins (TbpA, TbpA2  160 and TbpB), we expressed His-tagged TbpAs, TbpA2, and GST-tagged HsTbpB independently in 161 E. coli, and performed displacement ELISAs (Figure 2 ). E. coli does not encode any of these 162 three receptors and so this served as an appropriate heterologous system. TbpA assays were 163 . It . https://doi.org/10.1101/730739 doi: bioRxiv preprint 9 performed with whole cells while TbpB assays were performed with the soluble lysate fraction 164 (TbpB was expressed without its N-terminal cysteine and was therefore not lipidated). An 165 interaction was denoted as "specific" when unlabeled bovine transferrin lowered the absorbance 166 signal to 10% or less of the maximum and other unlabeled competitor transferrins did not 167 decrease the signal significantly. TbpA specifically bound bovine transferrin ( Figure 2B ). 168

Control TbpAs from the ruminant pathogen Mannheimia haemolytica and from the porcine 169 pathogen Actinobacillus pleuropneumoniae were used to validate the assay. The TbpAs from 170 these pathogens bound specifically to their cognate transferrins in our assay. We used a similar 171 approach to evaluate whether HsTbpB binding was specific for bovine transferrin. A 172 displacement ELISA using soluble GST-HsTbpB showed that unlike HsTbpA, HsTbpB binds 173 bovine, ovine, and caprine transferrins, but has higher affinity for bovine transferrin ( Figure 2C ). 174
Human transferrin was used as a negative control. 175

We also asked whether our strain of H. somni encoded a TbpA2, and whether this receptor was 176 as selective as TbpA. At the time these experiments were performed, a limited number of H. 177 somni genomes were available in NCBI and it was unclear how widespread TbpA2 was among 178 H. somni strains. We amplified out HsTbpA2 from strain H191, and cloned and expressed it in E. 179 coli. We then performed a displacement ELISA in the same way as had been performed for 180
TbpA. HsTbpA2 clearly bound bovine transferrin,which supports a previous report illustrating 181 that the H. somni TbpA2 homolog is a transferrin binding protein. Moreover, HsTbpA2 like, 182
HsTbpA, appears to selectively bind bovine transferrin in this assay ( Figure 2D ). 183

While our displacement ELISAs suggested that TbpB is responsible for the binding of H. somni 184 to multiple bovid transferrins, we decided to complement our competitive binding experiments 185 with direct binding assays to gain additional support for this result. We also measured binding of a TbpB from Neisseria 210 meningitidis, a human pathogen, to determine the affinity of TbpBs for non-cognate transferrins. 211

We observed no binding of NmTbpB to ovine transferrin within the concentration range used in 212 the experiment ( Figure 4D ). Taken together, our results suggest that H. somni TbpB is more 213 promiscuous than HsTbpA, and may, along with HsTbpA2, contribute to iron uptake from ovine Many pathogens have host species-specific receptors that arise from a process of coevolution 218 with the host. The sites that bear signatures of this coevolution tend to be functionally important, 219 and so identifying them can lend insight into how a given receptor functions. Furthermore, host-220 specific interactions restrict pathogens to infecting a single host species or a narrow range of host 221 species (31). This host specificity or host restriction can create a barrier to studying infection in 222 animal models. A better understanding of the underlying mechanism of specificity could lead to 223 the design of animal infection models that mimic the progress of disease more accurately(32). 224

The Tbps are host-specific receptors used by some host-restricted Proteobacteria for iron 225 acquisition. The interaction between Tbps and their cognate transferrin has been shown to be a 226 prerequisite for infection by Tbp-encoding bacteria. We looked for the most closely-related set of 227 transferrins that could be distinguished by a Tbp system and found a paper reporting that H. 228 somni binds bovine, but not ovine or caprine transferrins. Testing each receptor individually, we 229 found that H. somni TbpA showed no detectable affinity for ovine or caprine transferrins. 230 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license is made available under a The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the author/funder. It . https://doi.org/10.1101/730739 doi: bioRxiv preprint However, we found the TbpB and an additional transferrin binding TBDT, TbpA2, did bind 231 ovine and caprine transferrins. Furthermore, the affinities of HsTbpB for the ovine and caprine 232 transferrins is high enough to allow HsTbpB to bind them in the blood. We observed that H. 233 somni can utilize bovine, ovine, and caprine, but not human transferrin for growth. There are 234 four possibilities that can account for our observations; firstly, HsTbpA2 may work alone to 235 promote iron uptake from ovine and caprine transferrins; alternatively, HsTbpB may interact 236 with TbpA2 to promote iron uptake; finally, HsTbpB may work with HsTbpA to promote iron 237 uptake from the ovine and caprine transferrin C-lobes, with or without the accompaniment of 238

HsTbpA2, which is expected to take up iron from the N-lobe. A surface lipoprotein 239 compensating for lack of function in a TBDT is a phenomenon that has been observed 240 previously. For example,the function of a neisserial TbpA with mutations that reduced its 241 binding to human transferrin could be partially rescued when it was co-expressed with TbpB 242 (33). The mechanistic basis of this compensatory effect on the part of TbpB remains unknown. 243

One possibility is that TbpB binding increases the local concentration of transferrin in the area 244 around TbpA, thereby increasing the on rate enough to allow for iron uptake and thereby 245 promoting growth. Another possibility is that the association of the transferrin-TbpB complex 246
with TbpA leads to a conformational change that increases the affinity of TbpA for transferrin. 247

In this study, we conclude that TbpB can serve to broaden the host transferrin recognition range 248 of H. somni because its affinity for ovine and caprine transferrins is high enough to promote 249 binding in the blood. Our conclusions are based on reported serum transferrin concentrations. The H. somni transferrin receptors were chosen for specificity studies because they had been 268 reported to distinguish between very similar transferrins. However, we did not find the H. somni 269

Tbps to be as selective as reported. It is likely that the difference between our observations and 270 previously published results is due to differences in assay sensitivity. Furthermore, because 271

HsTbpA2 is phase variable, it is possible that HsTbpA2 was not expressed in the bacteria used in 272 the whole-cell binding assays of the previously published study, which means that TbpA 273 specificity may have had a larger relative effect on the results. It is worth noting that a previous 274 study that identified TbpA2 in another strain of H. somni also suggested that H. somni has two 275 sets of receptors, one specific for bovine transferrin and another that bound bovine, ovine, and 276 . It . https://doi.org/10.1101/730739 doi: bioRxiv preprint caprine transferrins (16). However, this paper does not conclusively determine which Tbps are 277 responsible for each binding pattern. 278
There were some discrepancies between the results obtained in the assays used in our study. 279

Firstly, while H. somni appears to grow to similar levels on ovine and caprine transferrins, it 280 appears to bind ovine transferrin with a higher affinity than caprine transferrin. This higher 281 relative affinity for ovine transferrin compared to caprine was also observed in experiments 282 using only HsTbpA2 and only HsTbpB. One possible explanation for this discrepancy is that 283 growth-promoting synergistic interactions between Tbps were not picked up in the binding 284 assays. Measuring the growth of tbpB and tbpA2 knockouts on various transferrin iron sources 285 would provide insight into whether and how these receptors work together. Secondly, binding of 286

HsTbpA2 to ovine and caprine transferrins was observed in the direct ELISA but not the 287 displacement ELISA (Figure 24D and 25B) . This is likely because the displacement ELISA did 288 not have sufficient dynamic range to capture this difference in affinity. This difference would 289 likely be observed at higher ratios of competitor to labeled transferrin. Interestingly, in the 290 HsTbpA2 displacement ELISA, the signal obtained using a competitor porcine transferrin was 291 significantly higher than the signal obtained with no competitor ( Figure 24D ). This points to a 292 flaw in the assay that cannot at present be explained. However, the difference in signal between 293 the ovine and porcine, and caprine and porcine columns was not significant. It is clear that a 294 more quantitative approach with purified TbpA2 is needed for follow-up binding assays. 295

Measuring the binding affinities between HsTbpA2 and the bovine, ovine, and caprine 296 transferrins would provide the most accurate information about the relative strengths of these 297 interactions. 298 . We originally intended to mutate residues in ovine transferrin to the corresponding residues in 299 bovine transferrin and screen for changes in affinity to the H. somni Tbps. This could still be 300 done to identify important sites of contact between the Tbps and transferrin. However, in the 301 case of HsTbpB and HsTbpA2, this would not be a screen for "all-or-none" changes in binding, 302 but instead would likely involve precise measurements of changes in affinity. BLI, or a similarly 303 sensitive technique that allows for quantitative binding analysis, would be ideal for these kinds 304 TBDT-dependent nutrient uptake systems can be either be monopartite, bipartite, or even 308 multipartite, such as the Sus system in Bacteroides (39). TBDTs do not inherently require 309 affiliated SLPs or other TBDTs to function. What then are the potential advantages of 310 multipartite systems? TbpA is always found in an operon with TbpB and the latter has been 311 shown to be essential for host colonization in the absence of lactoferrin receptors (12). However, 312 the reason for this is not understood. TbpB is hypothesized to be important because it 313 preferentially binds holo-transferrin. TbpA has no preference for transferrin's iron loaded state, 314 and so TbpB is thought to greatly increase the efficiency of iron acquisition. Furthermore, TbpA 315 and TbpB have been shown to function synergistically and together, have a higher affinity for 316 transferrin than either protein does alone. In this study we propose another advantage of having 317 an accessory SLP: the expansion of substrate range. In multipartite nutrient uptake systems such 318 as the Sus proteins, accessory lipoproteins are known to modulate substrate specificity (40). We 319

propose that HsTbpB also acts as a modulator, by broadening the specificity of the H. somni 320 transferrin receptor. 321 samples were centrifuged at 3000g to remove insoluble components and initially fractionated via 358 ammonium sulfate precipitation. As in the displacement ELISA, detergent-188 extracted HsTbpA bound bovine transferrin, and not ovine, caprine, or porcine transferrins 189 (Figure 3A). HsTbpA2, on the other hand, showed binding to bovine, ovine, and caprine 190 transferrins, although the absorbance signal for the latter two interactions was only a quarter of 191 what was observed for binding of HsTbpA2 to bovine transferrin (Figure 3B). 192 Because HsTbpA2 binds to ovine and caprine transferrins and is a member of the TBDT family, 193 we concluded that the growth observed in the presence of ovine and caprine transferrins must at 194 least be partially due to this receptor. In contrast, HsTbpB cannot act as a transporter, but may be 195 acting to promote iron uptake from ovine and caprine transferrins as well. To determine whether 196 the affinity of HsTbpB for ovine and caprine transferrins would allow it to bind these proteins at 197 physiological concentrations, we decided to measure binding affinities between the bovid 198 transferrins and HsTbpB. 199 200 The affinities of H. somni TbpB for ovine and caprine transferrins permit binding at 201 physiological concentrations 202 We measured dissociation constants (K D 's) for HsTbpB-transferrin interactions to determine if 203 binding occurs at physiological concentrations. We used bovine, ovine, and caprine transferrins 204 and compared the corresponding dissociation constants with the concentration of transferrin that 205 would be available in the host (Figure 4A-C,Table 7). While TbpB had a 3-fold lower affinity 206 for ovine transferrin and a 15.7-fold lower affinity for caprine transferrin compared to its affinity 207 for bovine transferrin, both dissociation constants are far lower than the concentration of 208

FIGREF4.text: 250While there is a range of reported values, healthy cattle have transferrin concentrations of 1.37 to 251 6.6 g/L (29, 30). Using a molecular weight of ~78 kDa for glycosylated bovine transferrin, the 252 transferrin concentration in the blood can be estimated to range between 17 to 85 µM. This is 253 the serum transferrin concentrations found in other animals (34). All of the transferrins 254 used in our experiments were fully iron loaded in order to remove a source of variability from 255 the experiments. However, only about 25-50% of the transferrin found in the blood is iron 256 saturated, meaning that in the blood, only ~10-25% of the transferrin C-lobes are in the holo 257 form(35). Because of this, the concentration ranges used in our experiments are approximately 258 representative of the amount of transferrin that is available as an iron source in the blood for 259Tbp-containing bacteria. Another important consideration is that H. somni usually resides on 260 mucosal surfaces where the transferrin concentration is significantly lower (although the exact 261 concentration is difficult to measure). In human saliva, for example, the concentration of 262 transferrin is roughly 10-50 nM (36-38). At these concentrations, the lower relative affinities of 263HsTbpB and HsTbpA2 for ovine and caprine transferrins compared to bovine transferrin may 264 become significant. H. somni is isolated from cattle more frequently than from sheep or goats. It 265 is possible that the concentration of transferrin on the mucosal surfaces of sheep and goats may 266 be low enough to pose a barrier to H. somni colonization. 267

FIGREF6.text: knowledge, H. somni is the only pathogen that has three transferrin binding proteins. 322 Whether HsTbpA2 leads to the formation of a tripartite receptor is unknown, but the possibility 323 is worth investigating. The three transferrin binding proteins in H. somni are reminiscent of the 324 receptors HpuAB and HmbR in the pathogenic Neisseria. HpuAB forms a TbpBA-like bipartite 325 receptor and binds hemoglobin-haptoglobin complexes, while HmbR is a single TBDT that binds 326 hemoglobin (41, 42). Like the corresponding H. somni genes, both hpuA and hmbR are phase 327 variable. Interestingly, the expression of HmbR has been correlated with a more virulent 328 phenotype (43, 44). It is unknown whether TbpA2 increases virulence in H. somni. However, it 329 is interesting to note that the commensal H. somni isolate 129PT (GenBank accession: 330 CP000436) has a frame-shifted TbpA2 while more virulent isolates such as strain 2336 331 (CP000947) do not display this frameshift (unpublished observations). In the same way that it 332 apparently benefits Neisseria to express three hemoglobin binding proteins, it may benefit H. 333 somni to express three Tbps. In addition to the ability to bind both lobes of transferrin, we 334 propose that having TbpBA and TbpA2 provides another advantage; HsTbpB and HsTbpA2 335 broaden transferrin recognition range to include ovine and caprine transferrins, and may play a 336 role in allowing H. somni to infect these bovid species. 337 338 d.
